Therefore, it is either only vast and boundless, or its extent is clear, or it is both vast and narrow, or vastness and narrowness are both negated, or it possesses the previous four, because it is the realm of understanding;
or it transcends the previous five, because it is the realm of practice.
The following all follow this principle.

However, this vastness and narrowness is also called pure and mixed. Universally pervading the Dharma realm, it is purely one without duality. Not destroying the original position, it does not obstruct the mixed.
The myriad practices are similar.
Third, this flower petal, having unfolded, pervades all dharmas, and then includes all dharmas to enter within itself.
Unfolding and embracing simultaneously, since there are no obstructions, therefore there is a melting or four statements or six statements. Contemplate it.
The text below says, One buddha land fills the ten directions, and the ten directions enter one without remainder.
If one is contrasted with all, then embracing and entering each have four statements, namely, one enters all, all enter one, one enters one, all enter all, mutually embracing is also like this.

Fourth, this one flower petal abandons itself and is the same as others, raising the entire body to be entirely those all dharmas, and always includes others as the same as itself, causing those all to be its own body.
One and many interpenetrate and merge without obstruction, but the realm of understanding and practice is different, with six statements the same as before.
The text below says knowing one is many, many is one, and so on. If the five flowers can include those, then one manifests and many are hidden.
If all include the flowers, then one is hidden and many are manifested.

Manifestation and manifestation are not simultaneous, and concealment and concealment are not parallel. Concealment and manifestation, manifestation and concealment, are simultaneously unobstructed. Completely including both, both are extinguished, and existence and nonexistence are both accomplished. The number of statements is the same as before.
The text below says entering concentration in the east and rising from concentration in the west, and so on. It is like the waxing and waning moon simultaneously appearing and disappearing.
Sixth, within the petals of this flower, subtle lands and all other phenomena are clearly present simultaneously.
The text below says all lands are vast and stable within a single dust mote.
And within a single hair-tip, there are unspeakably many tathÄgatas, as explained in the subtle aspects of the ninth stage of the ten grounds.

Seventh, in each and every dust mote of these flower petals, boundless ocean-like realms appear. Within each ocean-like realm, there are again dust motes, and within those dust motes, there are again ocean-like realms. In this way, layer upon layer, it is inexhaustible, not the realm of thought or cognition.

It is like Indra's palace covered with a net of jewels, where in each luminous jewel, myriad images appear together, and each jewel is like this. These jewels are clear and penetrating, mutually reflecting each other's images, with images reflecting images endlessly.
The text below says like the world of Indra's net and so on.
It is also like the lights of mirrors and lamps interreflecting endlessly, with Buddhas and Buddhas without end.
Eighth, seeing these flower petals is the same as seeing the inexhaustible Dharma realm, not relying on this to represent something else.
The text below says these canopies and so on arise from the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas and so on.
Ninth, since this one flower pervades all places, it also encompasses all times, namely the three times each multiplied by three, totaling ten times.
This is because time has no separate substance and is established based on the flower. Since the flower is unobstructed, time is also like it.
Therefore the Jin edition of the sutra says, Immeasurable kalpas in the past are placed in the present of the future;
Immeasurable kalpas in the future are placed in the past of the present.
The Samantabhadra Conduct says, The future is in the past, and the present is in the future, and so forth.
It also says, Immeasurable kalpas are a single thought, and a single thought is immeasurable kalpas, and so forth.
Since time has no separate substance, it is not established separately as a basis.
Tenth, the principles of this perfect teaching are not born alone, but must include retinue and arise accordingly.
Below it says, This flower immediately has ten world-systems of dust-mote-like flowers as its retinue.

It is also like one direction being the host and the ten directions being the companions, and the other directions are also like this. Therefore, the host and host, companions and companions, each do not see each other, and the host and companions, companions and host, are perfectly bright and endowed with virtue.
As the flower is raised, so are the other events such as a single particle and so forth.

In this way, the flower of events carries the ten meanings such as simultaneity, and is endowed with these ten approaches. However, these events and so forth are endowed with the other ten approaches such as teaching, and thus become one hundred approaches.
As the dharma of events is like this, the other teachings, meanings, and so forth, being endowed with one hundred, are also the same, and thus become one thousand approaches.

As the teachings, meanings, and so forth have these one thousand approaches, within the approach of simultaneity, they are also endowed with one hundred approaches. The other vast and narrow approaches are also like this, and also have one thousand approaches.
If one takes them layer upon layer, they also reach the inexhaustible.
If one clearly and perfectly manifests these ten approaches, one will always enter the realm of the Dharma realm layer upon layer.
Second, clarifying the causes and conditions of virtue and function.
Question:
What are the causes and conditions that allow these dharmas to have such a state of fusion without obstruction?
Answer:
The causes are vast and difficult to explain, so I will briefly mention ten categories:

1. Only manifested by the mind, 2. dharmas have no fixed nature, 3. the characteristics of dependent origination mutually rely on each other, 4. the nature of dharmas is fused, 5. like illusions and dreams, 6. like reflections and images, 7. the causes are limitless, 8. the Buddha's realization is ultimate, 9. the function of profound concentration, 10. the liberation of spiritual powers. Any one of the ten can cause those dharmas to be fused and unobstructed.
Among the ten, the first six generally take the nature of dharmas as the cause of merits and characteristics, and it is so by the principle of suchness;
The last two are both functions, and the meaning extends to causes and effects;
The seventh is about the cultivation of practice, and the meaning extends to merits, characteristics, and functions;
The eighth is about the merits of the fruition, and it is only the merits and characteristics.

The first ten approaches are common to merits, characteristics, and functions. If it is about the Buddha, the functions are also the merits and characteristics, because the functions are above the merits;
If it is about the capacity of sentient beings, the characteristics are also called functions, because it causes them to know the characteristics.

The characteristics that are used are both defiled and pure, and the function that is the characteristics can both defile and purify, therefore the characteristics and function are not divided into two separate things.

First, only the mind appears: all dharmas are manifested by the true mind, like the entire body of the ocean becoming waves. Since all dharmas are none other than the one mind, the characteristics of large and small, etc., follow the turning of the mind and immediately enter into unobstructedness.
Second, dharmas have no fixed nature: since they only appear from the mind and arise from conditions, they have no fixed nature, and both nature and characteristics are absent.
Small is not definitely small, therefore it can contain the great void and have more, because it is the same as the great without an outside;
great is not definitely great, therefore it can enter the small dust without obstruction, because it is the same as the small without an inside.

Then, what difficulty is there in having a dust mote equal to the great void, or containing a vast world in a dust mote? The old sÅ«tra's chapter on the ten abodes says: The number of vajra-encircling mountains can all be placed on the tip of a single hair.
If you want to know the great has small characteristics, the bodhisattva initiates this first thought.
One is not definitely one, therefore it can be all;
Many are not definitely many, therefore it can be one.ğŸ”½The extreme is not definitely the extreme, therefore it can be the middle;
The middle is not definitely the middle, therefore it can be the extreme.
Prolonging, shortening, stillness, confusion, etc., each is so.

Third, the characteristics of dependent origination are mutually dependent. It means that in the great Dharma realm, the ocean of dependent origination has immeasurable Dharma gates. Based on the perfect teaching, ten gates are briefly presented to explain the previous meaning. It means that the Dharma of dependent origination must possess these ten meanings before it can arise. If any is lacking, it will not be accomplished.

First, the meaning of the difference of each condition. It means that in the great dependent origination, the conditions must have separate essence and function, without confusion, in order to form dependent origination.
If there is confusion, the original condition Dharma will be lost, and dependent origination will not be accomplished.
This means that the various conditions each guard their own position. The text says, In the many there is no single nature, and in the one there are also many.
Second, the meaning of mutual pervasion and mutual assistance. This means that these conditions must mutually pervade and respond in order to form conditioned arising.
For example, when one condition pervades and responds to many conditions, it completely becomes one with each of those many, so this one possesses many ones.
If this one condition does not possess many ones, then the assistance and response will not be pervasive and will not form conditioned arising.
This means that each and every one possesses all, as the text below says, Knowing that because of one there are many, knowing that because of many there is one.
Third, the meaning of unobstructed coexistence. This means that any single condition must possess the first two in order to form conditioned arising.
Because it must abide in its own position in order to be able to pervade and respond, pervading and responding to many conditions is precisely being one.
Therefore, being the only one and being many ones are freely unobstructed and fused.
There are six statements:
First, when the entire body completely abides, this is the one.
Second, when the entire body universally responds, this is the many in the one;
Third, when both are present, Fourth, when both are negated, Fifth, when they are combined, and Sixth, when they are completely separated, all can be seen by thinking about them.
The text says, All dharmas have no basis, but arise from a combination.
This concludes the general explanation of the three gates of the fundamental dharma of dependent origination.

Fourth, the meaning of the mutual interpenetration of different substances, which means that the power and function of the various gates mutually rely on and uphold each other, and mutually form each other.
Each has the meaning of having complete power and having no power, only then can dependent origination be established.
As the treatise says, Because the cause does not produce, the conditions produce.
Because the conditions do not produce, the self-cause produces.ğŸ”½If each only has power and no powerlessness, then there is the fault of multiple effects, because each produces individually.
If each only has no power and no power, then there is the fault of having no effect, because they are the same as non-conditions and do not produce together.
Therefore, dependent origination must mutually rely on each other, with strength and weakness. If one condition is missing, everything is not accomplished.
The other cases are also like this.
Therefore, one can hold many, one has strength and can hold many;
many rely on one, many are weak and merge into one.
Because one has strength, it definitely does not coexist with many that have strength, therefore there is no one that does not include many;
because many are weak, they definitely do not coexist with one that is weak, therefore there is no many that does not enter one.
Just as one holds many and relies on them, many hold one and rely on it as well. Think about it in the opposite way.

Just as one, in relation to many, has reliance, has support, has full strength and no strength, always includes many within itself and merges into many within itself, simultaneously without obstruction;
many in relation to one should be understood in the same way.
Both existence and both extinction, the two phrases are unobstructed, think about it.

The fifth is the meaning of mutual identity of different natures, which means that when conditions are compared with each other, their entire substance is mutually negated. Only when there is the meaning of having substance and not having substance can conditioned arising be accomplished. If a single condition is lacking, the others cannot arise, and therefore the meaning of conditions is destroyed.

Obtaining this single condition allows everything to arise and be accomplished. Because what arises is accomplished, the meaning of conditions is established. Therefore, a single condition is able to give rise to and accomplish, and thus has substance. Many conditions are what is given rise to and accomplished, and thus have no substance.

Because a single substance with substance cannot coexist with many substances with substance, and many substances without substance must not coexist with a single substance without substance, therefore there is not a single that is not many, and there is not a many that is not one.
If one and many are like this, many and one are also so. Think about it in the opposite way.

Just as one, when compared with many, has substance and no substance, and thus can include others and make them the same as itself, and discard itself and make it the same as others, simultaneously without obstruction;
When many are compared with one, you should know it is also like this. Think about it according to the previous explanation.
Both existence and extinction, the two phrases unobstructed, can also be seen by thinking about it.

Sixth, the meaning of the mutual identity and interpenetration of the essence and function of all dharmas, that is, all conditioned dharmas must have their power and function interpenetrating and their entire essence merging in order to form conditioned arising.
Therefore, the perfect interfusion also has six phrases:
First, because the essence has no function that is not used, the entire essence is completely functional, then there is only mutual entry and no mutual identity.
Second, because the function has no essence that is not included, the entire function is completely essential, then there is only mutual identity and no mutual entry.

Third, the function that returns to the essence does not obstruct the function, and the essence that is completely functional does not lose its essence. This is the unobstructed simultaneous existence of both entry and identity, freely appearing together.
Fourth, the essence that is completely functional is extinguished;
The function that is completely essential is lost.
Neither identical nor entered, perfectly fused into one flavor.
Fifth, combining the previous four phrases, they are the same conditioned arising, unobstructed, and simultaneously existent.
Sixth, the previous five statements are obliterated, beyond comparison, and ineffable, merging with the ocean of nature.
The above three approaches are fully revealed within the first approach of distinct essence.

Seventh, the approach of the mutual inclusion of the same essence means that the many ones that exist in a single condition are not separate from the essence of that single condition, and are therefore called the same essence.

Moreover, because this single condition should be many conditions, there are these many ones. Since the many conditions that it should be are mutually inclusive, it causes these many ones to also have mutual inclusion.

First, mutual inclusion is clarified. It means that a single condition has power and can uphold many ones, while many ones are powerless and rely on that single condition. Therefore, one can encompass many, and many immediately enter one;
one enters many and encompasses, the opposite of the above should be known.
The other meanings and other statements should be contemplated based on the previous.

Eighth, the approach of the mutual identity of the same essence means that the many ones possessed by a single condition also have the meaning of having essence and not having essence, and therefore are also mutually identical.

Because many and one are without substance, they are accomplished by the original one, and many are identical with one;ğŸ”½Because the original one has substance, it can make many and one, causing one to include many.
Just as one has many voids, so too does many have one void.
The other meanings and other phrases should all be contemplated according to the previous [sections].
The ninth meaning of unobstructed interpenetration, namely, also the same as the previous mutual interpenetration of essence and function, is freely interpenetrating.
There are also six phrases, which should be understood according to the previous [sections].
The above three sections explain the meaning and principle within the second section on the same essence.
The tenth meaning of perfect identity and difference, namely, combining the previous nine sections into one great conditioned arising, causing many kinds of meanings to be simultaneously complete.
Because of abiding in one universal response, there is the gate of vastness and narrowness at will.
Because of being based on essence and function, there is the gate of mutual identity and mutual entry.

Because of the mutual containment of different essences, there is the gate of subtle inclusion. Because of the mutual identity of different essences, there is the gate of hidden and revealed inclusion.

Furthermore, in terms of the apparent aspect of function, entering is manifested, while in terms of the essential aspect, entering is concealed. The same is true for manifesting and concealing in the case of entering.

Moreover, due to different approaches, entering is manifested, while in terms of the same essence, entering is concealed. The same is true for manifesting and concealing in the case of difference and sameness.
Furthermore, due to different essences entering while carrying the same essence entering, the Indra's net approach is complete.
Because of this great dependent arising, there is the unobstructed Dharma realm, and therefore there is the approach of phenomena manifested by relying on events.
Because it is manifested within time, there is the approach of the ten times.
Because they are mutually inclusive, there is the approach of the host and its retinue.

This tenth complete approach is discussed within the third approach above, so the text below says, Bodhisattvas skillfully observe the Dharma of dependent arising. In one Dharma, they understand many. In many Dharmas, they understand one.
It also says, In one, they understand the immeasurable. In the immeasurable, they understand one. Understanding their mutual arising, they will attain fearlessness. These are all its meanings.
The above concludes the section on the arising of dependent origination.
The fourth is the section on the interpenetration of the nature of dharmas. This means that if one only discusses phenomena, they mutually obstruct each other and cannot be immediately included;
if one only discusses principle, then there is only one flavor and nothing to be immediately included.

Now, principle and phenomena interpenetrate and are endowed with this unobstructedness. This means that one phenomenon that is not different from principle, when it fully includes principle, causes the many phenomena that are not different from principle to all appear within the one, following the principle upon which they are based.
If the principle is not fully included within the one, then the true principle has the fault of being limited;
if the principle is fully included within the one, but the many phenomena do not appear in accordance with the principle, then the phenomena are outside of the principle.
Now, since the one phenomenon fully includes the principle, how could the many phenomena not appear within the one?
The Chapter on the Repository of Adornments says: In each dust mote of the Repository of Adornments world, the Dharma realm is seen.
The Dharma realm is precisely the realm of phenomena.
This is the general meaning.
The ten mysteries are also complete in each one:
First, since true principle is in accord with all dharmas, encompassing principle without remainder, it is the simultaneous and complete possession of all gates and all dharmas.

Second, since events are able to contain according to principle, they are also as vast and pervasive as principle without destroying the narrow characteristics, thus there is the unobstructed gate of vastness, narrowness, purity, and mixture.
Moreover, because the nature is always equal, it is pure; because it universally includes all dharmas, it is mixed.
Third, since principle is universally present in all many events, it causes a single event to follow principle and be universally present in all of them.
If principle is universally present in a single event, then all follow principle;
because it is present in a single event, there is the gate of the mutual containment of one and many.
Fourth, since true principle is not apart from all dharmas, then a single event is true principle, and true principle is all events, therefore this one is those all events;
all are one, the opposite can be understood, thus there is the gate of mutual identity and sovereignty.

Fifth, because reality is entirely in each phenomenon without being a part of it, when it is in this one it is said to be hidden in that one, and when it is in that one it is hidden in this one. Therefore there is the gate of concealment and manifestation.
Sixth, since reality universally includes all phenomena, it includes those phenomena that it supports, all at once, in one. Therefore there is the subtle gate.
Seventh, because this one completely includes reality, it can manifest all of them. The reality that they completely include is the same as this one, manifested all at once.
When this one manifests that one, the one that can manifest and what is manifested are both manifested in this one.
When that one manifests this one, the one that can manifest and what is manifested are also manifested in that one.
In this way, the layers are endless. Therefore there is the Indra's net gate, because suchness is ultimately inexhaustible.
Eighth, because phenomena are the same as reality, taking up any one phenomenon is a true Dharma gate. Therefore there is the gate of relying on phenomena.

Ninth, because suchness is universally present, day and night, years, months, and eons are all completely present. When present in a day, it is no different than when present in an eon. Therefore there is the gate of the accomplishment of the differences of the ten times.
How much more so when time exists due to dharmas, and dharmas are fused in time but not fused in time?
Ten, this principle is the principle of time, which does not obstruct the constant correspondence with the rest, therefore there is the gate of the host and retinue.
Therefore, one principle is fused and pervaded, and the ten gates are complete.
Five, like an illusion or dream, just like an illusionist who can transform one thing into many kinds, and transform many kinds of things into one thing, etc.
The sutra says, Sometimes appearing for a moment as a hundred years, etc.
All dharmas are created by the illusion of karma, therefore there is no obstruction of sameness or difference.
As for being like a dream, it is like what is seen in a dream, a vast place without moving from one's pillow, and a long time without passing a short while.
Therefore the treatise says, In a dream one thinks it is a year, but upon awakening it is only a short while.
Therefore, although time is immeasurable, it is included in a single instant.
Six, like a reflection, all myriad dharmas have two meanings in brief:
First, they are all like a clear mirror reflecting light, because they are accomplished by the nature of the one mind.
Second, they are manifested by discrimination, like images.

Because of the first meaning, they are the illuminator, and because of the latter meaning, they are the illuminated. Therefore, all dharmas are mirrors for each other, like mirrors reflecting each other without destroying their original forms.
The sutra below says, Although distant objects and near objects are all reflected, the reflections do not follow the objects in being distant or near.

Seventh, the causes are limitless. This means that the buddhas and bodhisattvas, while still in the causal stage, always cultivated the contemplation of dependent origination and the absence of nature, the great vows and dedications that accord with the Dharma realm, and other immeasurable superior causes. Now, the fruits that arise in accordance with those causes possess this unobstructedness.
Eighth, the buddhas have thoroughly realized. This is because by merging with the true nature, they attain the function of suchness.
Therefore, the sutra says, Because of incomparable merit, one is able to do so.
Ninth, the function of profound concentration. This refers to the power of various samÄdhis such as the ocean seal samÄdhi.
The Chapter on the Foremost of Worthies says, Entering samÄdhis as numerous as dust motes, each giving rise to samÄdhis equal to the dust motes, yet those dust motes do not increase.
As for the ten supernatural powers and liberations, it means due to the ten supernatural powers and inconceivable liberations, etc.
Among the ten kinds of liberations in the Chapter on Inconceivable Dharmas, it says, Establishing the dharmas of all buddhas of the three times in a single dust mote, etc.
Due to the above ten causes, it causes the previous ten pairs of teachings and meanings, etc.,
